title: Research Reference
text:
The GitHub repository is the primary public-facing repository, while the GIN repository hosts annex-files as a common data source. If you would like to view the files without having to clone/download the Datalad dataset, you please visit the GIN repository.
Current status: Most of my lab protocols documented in my LabArchives Notebooks and also kept on our Microsoft 365 infrastructure. I’m creating this Datalad dataset to try an ‘open’ format, which doesn’t require authentication to view and allows others to comment on the contents.
If you have any questions, comments, or critiques, please do not hesitate to open an issue on GitHub.

title: Research Reference
text:
About this dataset

General information
This is a DataLad dataset (id: 3d6beff7-a55d-43a2-ab44-6def6a79bde5).


DataLad datasets and how to use them
This repository is a DataLad dataset. It provides fine-grained data access down to the level of individual files, and allows for tracking future updates. In order to use this repository for data retrieval, DataLad is required. It is a free and open source command line tool, available for all major operating systems, and builds up on Git and git-annex to allow sharing, synchronizing, and version controlling collections of large files.
More information on how to install DataLad and how to install it can be found in the DataLad Handbook.

Get the dataset
A DataLad dataset can be cloned by running
datalad clone <url>
Once a dataset is cloned, it is a light-weight directory on your local machine. At this point, it contains only small metadata and information on the identity of the files in the dataset, but not actual content of the (sometimes large) data files.


Retrieve dataset content
After cloning a dataset, you can retrieve file contents by running
datalad get <path/to/directory/or/file>
This command will trigger a download of the files, directories, or subdatasets you have specified.
DataLad datasets can contain other datasets, so called subdatasets. If you clone the top-level dataset, subdatasets do not yet contain metadata and information on the identity of files, but appear to be empty directories. In order to retrieve file availability metadata in subdatasets, run
datalad get -n <path/to/subdataset>
Afterwards, you can browse the retrieved metadata to find out about subdataset contents, and retrieve individual files with datalad get. If you use datalad get <path/to/subdataset>, all contents of the subdataset will be downloaded at once.


Stay up-to-date
DataLad datasets can be updated. The command datalad update will fetch updates and store them on a different branch (by default remotes/origin/master). Running
datalad update --merge
will pull available updates and integrate them in one go.


Find out what has been done
DataLad datasets contain their history in the git log. By running git log (or a tool that displays Git history) in the dataset or on specific files, you can find out what has been done to the dataset or to individual files by whom, and when.

title: Key Resources Table in Markdown
text: Adapted from the Cell Press STAR Methods to help produce Structured, Transparent, Accessible Reporting in research.

title: Key Resources Table in Markdown
section: Markdown Code to Copy and Paste

title: Datalad with GitHub and GIN siblings
text:
datalad create-sibling-gin --access-protocol https-ssh \
  --credential gin@g-node.org \
  -r research-reference \
  --dry-run

datalad create-sibling-github -s github --credential github_pm90_sibling -r research-reference --dry-run

dd if=/dev/zero of=binary.dat bs=1c count=1

git config --unset-all remote.gin.annex-ignore

datalad push --to gin

datalad siblings configure --name gin --as-common-datasrc gin-src

datalad push --to gin



CitationBibTeX citation:@online{mishra2023,
  author = {Pranav Mishra},
  title = {Datalad with {GitHub} and {GIN} Siblings},
  date = {2023-04-24},
  url = {https://github.com/pranavmishra90/research-reference/readme.html},
  langid = {en-US}
}
For attribution, please cite this work as:
Pranav Mishra. 2023. “Datalad with GitHub and GIN
Siblings.” April 24, 2023. https://github.com/pranavmishra90/research-reference/readme.html.

title: Adding tables easily to this site
text: To easily interchange between the formats, paste your table into https://tablesgenerator.com/markdown_tables

title: Adding tables easily to this site
text:
Markdown
The easiest way to add tables into a .qmd file is to add it as a markdown formatted table. Here is an example from w3schools:
|Header1 |Header2  | Header3|
--- | --- | ---|
|data1|data2|data3|
|data11|data12|data13|

Output



Header1
Header2
Header3




data1
data2
data3


data11
data12
data13

title: Adding tables easily to this site
text:
HTML with CSS You can also place the same table using HTML
Header1 Header2 Header3
data1 data2 data3
data11 data12 data13
Output Header1 Header2 Header3 data1 data2 data3 data11 data12 data13

title: About
text:
This is open-access site for research protocols, files, and techniques which I use. It is in an extreme infancy phase and is undergoing active development.
Thanks for visiting
Pranav

title: Tris-Glycine SDS Running Buffer
text:
Tris-Gycine Transfer Buffer has a pH of 8.3. Protocol adapted from Abcam and ThermoFicher1, 2


Running buffer for Western Blot

title: Tris-Glycine SDS Running Buffer
text:
Components

Tris Base
Glycine
\(HCl\)
\(diH_2O\)

title: Tris-Glycine SDS Running Buffer
text:
Protocol

10x Stock

Add 700 mL of \(diH_2O\) to a beaker
Dissolve 29 g of Tris base, 144 g of Glycine, and 10 g of SDS
Adjust pH using \(HCl\), as needed
Add \(diH_2O\) until the total volume reaches 1 L of solution

Concentration of 1x Tris-Glycine SDS 25 mM Tris base, 190 mM glycine, 0.1% SDS

title: Tris-Glycine SDS Running Buffer
text: Notes

title: Tris-Glycine SDS Running Buffer
text:
References

Transfer and staining of proteins in western blot. Abcam. https://www.abcam.com/protocols/transfer-and-staining-of-proteins-in-western-blot
Western Blot Protocols and Recipes. ThermoFicher Scientific. https://www.thermofisher.com/us/en/home/life-science/protein-biology/protein-biology-learning-center/protein-gel-electrophoresis-information/western-blot-protocols.html

title: Recipe: Tris-Buffered Saline (TBS)
text:
Tris (trishydroxymethylaminomethane) \((HOCH_2)_3CNH_2\) has an effective buffer range between 7.1 and 9.1 (pKa 8.07 at \(25 ^\circ C\))


Wash buffer in Western Blots

title: Recipe: Tris-Buffered Saline (TBS)
text:
Components

\(diH_2O\)
Tris Base (Ficher BP154-1)

Alternate Trizma HCl 24.23g

\(12 N\space HCl\)
\(HCl\)

title: Recipe: Tris-Buffered Saline (TBS)
text:
Protocol

Comparison of TBS concentrations at 1x



Component
Abcam (mM)
Abcam (g)
Thermo (mM)
Thermo (g)




Tris base
20
2.4
20
2.4


NaCl
150
8.8
150
8.8





10x stock solution
We will be preparing 1L of 10x TBS for a stock solution.

Add 800 mL of \(diH_2O\) to orange top container
Dissolve 24 g of Tris Base and 88 g \(NaCl\) into the container
Titrate the pH with \(12 N\space HCl\) to 7.6
Add \(diH_2O\) to bring the total volume to 1 L

10x concentrations: - Tris 200 mM - \(NaCl\) 1500 mM


1x TBS solution
using the 10x solution described above

Add 100 mL of 10x TBS solution to an orange top container
Add 900 mL of \(diH_2O\)
Adjust pH to 7.6 using \(12 N\space HCl\) (currently have 2N stock in the lab, will require more acid being used to neutralize)

1x concentrations: - Tris 20 mM - \(NaCl\) 150 mM

title: Recipe: Tris-Buffered Saline (TBS)
text:
Notes
Abcam and Thermo have protocols in agreement. Phosphosolutions proposes 2mM Tris, 14 mM NaCl, 0.1% Tween-20, pH 7.6.
We currently have 2N HCl stock in the lab, so it requires significantly more HCl added to neutralize the Tris Base.

title: Tris-Buffered Saline with Tween 20 (TBST)
text:
Tween-20 is a non-ionic detergent which acts as a temporary blocking agent to prevent non-specific protein-protein binding. In western blots, after the primary antibody has been allowed to bind appropriately, we need to prepare for the secondary antibody. First, we must wash the membrane to remove all excess primary antibody. By washing the membrane with a detergent, we prevent the primary antibody from inadventantly, incorrectly binding to an incorrect site (non-specific binding to the membrane). The antibody will have a preferential binding to the detergent.
Detergents are helpful temporary blockers - they can be washed away easily with aqeuous solutions.

title: Tris-Buffered Saline with Tween 20 (TBST)
text:
Components

10x Stock TBS
Tween 20
\(diH\_2O\)

title: Tris-Buffered Saline with Tween 20 (TBST)
text:
Protocol

Add 800 mL of \(diH\_2O\) to orange top container
Add 1 mL of Tween 20 using a wide tip pipette (Tween 20 is very viscous)
Add ~199 mL of \(diH\_2O\) down the side of the container until the total volume reaches 1 L

title: Tris-Buffered Saline with Tween 20 (TBST)
text:
Notes
Do not start with a 1x TBS that we may keep at the bench. This will have 20% Methanol added, which we do not want for TBST.

title: Tris-Buffered Saline with Tween 20 (TBST)
text:
References

Western blot buffers and stock solutions. Abcam. https://www.abcam.com/protocols/buffer-and-stock-solutions-for-western-blot

title: Tris-Glycine Transfer Buffer
text:
Tris-Gycine Transfer Buffer has a pH of 8.3. Protocol adapted from Abcam1


Transfer buffer used in Western Blots

title: Tris-Glycine Transfer Buffer
text:
Components

Tris Base
Glycine
\(HCl\)
100% Methanol
\(diH_2O\)

title: Tris-Glycine Transfer Buffer
text:
Protocol

10x Stock of Transfer Buffer

Add 700 mL of \(diH_2O\) to a beaker
Dissolve 30.25 g of Tris Base and 142.63 g of Glycine in the water
Adjust pH with \(HCl\) to 8.3
Add 300mL of \(diH_2O\) (total vol 1000 mL)



1x Transfer Buffer

Add 700 mL of \(diH_2O\) to a beaker
Add 100 mL of 10x Stock Transfer Buffer
Adjust pH with \(HCl\) to 8.3
Add 200mL of 100% Methanol (total vol 1000 mL)

1x concentrations: - Tris 25 mM - Glycine 190 mM

title: Tris-Glycine Transfer Buffer
text:
Notes
Concentrations of Tris and Glycine differ from ThermoFicher’s protocols2, which recommend a 12.5 mM of Tris and 96 mM Glycine.



Component
Abcam (mM)
Thermo (mM)




Tris base
25
12.5


Glycine

96

title: Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS)
text:
Similar pH, electrolytes, and osmolarity to the human body.

Concentration: 1x
pH 7.4




Washing tissues, cells
Common base solvent in many solutions

title: Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS)
text:
Components

\(NaCl\)
\(KCl\)
\(Na_2HPO_4\)
\(KH_2PO_4\)
\(diH_20\)
1L sterile container

title: Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS)
text:
Preparation for 1L of 1x PBS

Add 800 mL of \(diH_20\) a sterile container
Add electrolytes

8g \(NaCl\)
0.2g \(KCl\)
1.44g \(Na_2HPO_4\)
0.245g \(KH_2PO_4\)

Adjust pH to 7.4 by titrating appropriate amounts of \(Na_2HPO_4\) or \(KH_2PO_4\)

title: Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS)
text:
Preparation for 1L of 10x PBS

Add 800 mL of \(diH_20\) a sterile container
Add electrolytes

80g \(NaCl\)
2g \(KCl\)
14.4g \(Na_2HPO_4\)
2.45g \(KH_2PO_4\)

Adjust pH to 7.4 by titrating appropriate amounts of \(Na_2HPO_4\) or \(KH_2PO_4\)

title: Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS)
text:
References:

Phosphate-buffered saline (Pbs). Cold Spring Harb Protoc. 2006;2006(1):pdb.rec8247. doi:10.1101/pdb.rec8247

title: 10% Formalin (4% Paraformaldehyde)
text:
The term “Formalin” specifically refers to a saturated solution of Formaldehyde, which is 37% w/v or about 40% v/v. This is a rather high concentration of formaldehyde. A common dilution is a 1:10, which is referred to as 10% Formalin or 4% Formaldehyde (aka 4% Paraformaldehyde). “Paraformaldehyde” technically refers to a polymerized form of formaldehyde which is stable at room temperature without the addition of methanol. Upon addition to an aqueous solution, it dissolves into formaldehyde by breaking the polymer chain.


Fixing tissue

title: 10% Formalin (4% Paraformaldehyde)
text:
Components

\(diH_2O\)
\(HCl\) (Dilute)
\(NaOH\) (1 N)
Paraformaldehyde powder (Sigma Aldrich Cat 158127-500G)
1X Phosphate Buffered Saline
Sterile container

title: 10% Formalin (4% Paraformaldehyde)
section: Protocol: Preparation of 1 liter of 4% PFA (10% Formalin)
text:
Protocol: Preparation of 1 liter of 4% PFA (10% Formalin)

In a vented hood, add 800 mL of PBS to a beaker with a stir bar on a hot plate set to \(60 ^\circ C\)
Add 40g of PFA powder to the heated PBS solution
Spin until mostly disolved
Raise the pH, dropwise, by adding 1N \(NaOH\) until the solution clears
Cool to room temperature
Add 1x PBS until the volume reaches 1L total

title: 10% Formalin (4% Paraformaldehyde)
text:
Storage

Ideally, this should be prepared fresh for each use
\(2-8 ^\circ C\): 1 month
\(-20 ^\circ C\): several months

title: 10% Formalin (4% Paraformaldehyde)
text:
References

R&D Systems. Protocol for Making a 4% Formaldehyde Solution in PBS. https://www.rndsystems.com/resources/protocols/protocol-making-4-formaldehyde-solution-pbs
